results.title: Beginning of life
results.brief_description: Scientists study nature and experiment to discover the basis of evolution. By tracing the history of the element carbon, the evolution of organic matter from cosmic matter to unicellular and multi-cellular organisms is known. Experiments synthesizing complex organic matter from simple substances prove the importance of carbon in the evolution of life; amino acids can be synthesized which are linked with proteins and important to life. No credits available.

results.title: Beginning of history
results.creator_credit: Graham Wallace and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: By using the remains of things made and built by prehistoric man to reconstruct a prehistoric dwelling, this film ambitiously attempts to tell the story of what happened in the ages before the period at which most history books begin. The co-operation of many world famous British museums, societies, and foundations has helped to make this reconstruction, (especially the Iron Age farm), authentic. No credits available.

results.title: Beginning french: intonation
results.brief_description: Compares the characteristic patterns of French and English intonation in a number of every-day phrases and sentences. Analysing French intonation, a class of students learn to listen for basic patterns and their variations, and how to reproduce the characteristic “music” of French speech. Stresses the importance of practice in listening as well as in speaking. No other credits available.

results.title: Beginning (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merry-Go-Round Sex Education. - Part 1.”.
The first in a three part series of sex-education films for young children, “Beginning” uses cross references in the animal world to explain embryonic growth and development. A microscope shows the process of cell division in the egg, and animated drawings reveal the embryo’s position in the body. Method of nourishment, and developmental changes to five months.

results.title: Beginners please
results.creator_credit: Exclusive Films, Gaumont-British Instructional, BFI and Donald Carter
results.brief_description: All physical training must be begun gently; gymnastics should be started with light excerises. This film demonstrates games designed to ease the muscles before going on to more strenuous and involved movements.

results.title: Beginners please
results.creator_credit: South Australian Housing Trust and Colin Ballantyne
results.brief_description: A brief survey of Elizabeth, South Australia focusing on the history of the building of the twin theatres, the Octagon (an eight-sided structure) and the Shedley (smaller and more intimate).

results.title: Beginner's guide to cake decorating. Pt. 1
results.brief_description: Robyn Hamilton demonstrates cake decorating techniques for the beginner. This part teaches icing, piping, flower making, arranging and assembling.

results.title: Beggars of life [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Paramount Famous Lasky Corporation, Jesse L Lasky, Adolph Zukor and William Wellman
results.brief_description: Luminous silent screen personality Louise Brooks stars in this drama about the trials and tribulations of life on the run from the law. A hungry, disheveled hobo gets more than he bargains for when he staggers toward a farmhouse in search of a hot meal. To his amazement, he finds an old man with a gunshot wound to the head and a frightened girl with a heartbreaking story to tell. Feeling sorry for her, he offers to help her hop a freight train to safety. Disguised as a boy to make traveling easier the girl agrees, but despite the hobo’s best intentions to help her on her way, they end up traversing the countryside together. However, their journey is not an easy one as they attract scorn and loathing from the people they meet, hostility and suspicion from other hobos, and unwelcome attention from the police during their quest to reach Canada and forge new lives for themselves. “Beggars of Life” is loosely based on the novel “A Hobo Autobiography” (1924) by Jum Tully a popular author of the 1920’s and 1930’s and one of the founders of the school of hard-boiled writing in the United States. Stars Louise Brooks as The Girl (Nancy), Richard Arlen as The Boy (Jim), Wallace Beery as Oklahoma Red, and Robert Perry as The Arkansaw Snake.

results.title: Before we ruled the earth
results.creator_credit: Bill Latka, Evergreen Films, Discovery Channel and Pier De Lespinois
results.brief_description: Using dramatic historical re-enactments and computer animation this documentary provides a fascinating insight into the world of prehistoric life and the eventual evolution of the human race from primitive Homo ergaster to Homo erectus, from the rise of the Neanderthals and the Pleistocene era of the Cro-Magnons, to the advanced sophistication of the Paleo-Indians. We see how humans battle to survive alongside such prehistoric predatory beasts as the sabretooth cat, woolly mammoths and gigantic bears in often extreme conditions where it truly is the “survival of the fittest”. Episode 1. Hunt or be hunted: Begins in prehistoric Africa 1.7 million years ago with Homo ergaster and fast-forwards a million years to Homo erectus through to the Cro-Magnons. Discusses the evolutionary process and the importance of adapting to climatic and environmental changes, of developing skills to master the art of survival and of how the discovery of fire-making played such an important role in the evolution story. Episode 2. Mastering the beasts: Follows the Cro-Magnons to America revealing their tenacity in surviving harsh elements, extreme hunger and the company of woolly mammoths. Also focuses on the Paleo-Indians of North America as two small bands come together for a ritual buffalo kill. Based on available scientific evidence, this interpretive program is highly recommended as an educational tool. Narrated by John Slattery, story by Brian Fagan.
